Get Started with glyexp

glyexp.Rmd

ğŸš§ Under Construction Alert!
glyexp is hot off the press and still evolving rapidly.
Think of it as your shiny new lab equipment thatâ€™s being fine-tuned.
Not quite ready for the big leagues yet, but getting there fast!

Picture this: youâ€™re knee-deep in omics experiments (especially the fascinating world of glycomics and glycoproteomics), and youâ€™re juggling three types of data like a lab virtuoso:

  1. Expression data - the actual measurements of your biological molecules (glycans, glycopeptides, and their friends)
  2. Molecular annotations - the ID cards for your molecules (structures, sequences, you name it)
  3. Experimental metadata - the story behind your samples (time points, treatments, experimental conditions)

Hereâ€™s where glyexp swoops in to save the day! ğŸ¦¸â€â™€ï¸

The experiment() class is your new best friend - think of it as a smart container that keeps all three data types organized and talking to each other. No more scattered spreadsheets or lost annotations!

Why should you care? Every package in the glycoverse ecosystem speaks experiment() fluently. Itâ€™s like having a universal translator for your glycomics workflow - everything just clicks together.

library(glyexp)
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

Your First Steps into the Glycoverse

Letâ€™s dive in with our trusty toy experiment - think of it as your training wheels before you tackle the real deal.

toy_exp <- toy_experiment()
toy_exp
#> 
#> â”€â”€ Experiment â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
#> â„¹ Expression matrix: 6 samples, 4 variables
#> â„¹ Sample information fields: group and batch
#> â„¹ Variable information fields: protein, peptide, and glycan_composition

Look at that beautiful summary! When you print an experiment() object, itâ€™s like getting a snapshot of your entire experimental world - variables, observations, and all the metadata that makes your data meaningful.

Now, letâ€™s peek under the hood. You can extract the three core components faster than you can say â€œglycosylationâ€:

ğŸ§¬ The Expression Matrix - Your Dataâ€™s Heart and Soul 

get_expr_mat(toy_exp)
#>    S1 S2 S3 S4 S5 S6
#> V1  1  5  9 13 17 21
#> V2  2  6 10 14 18 22
#> V3  3  7 11 15 19 23
#> V4  4  8 12 16 20 24

This matrix is where the magic happens - rows are your variables (molecules), columns are your observations (samples), and the numbers tell your biological story.

ğŸ·ï¸ Variable Information - Meet Your Molecules 

get_var_info(toy_exp)
#> # A tibble: 4 Ã— 4
#>   variable protein peptide glycan_composition
#>   <chr>    <chr>   <chr>   <chr>             
#> 1 V1       PRO1    PEP1    H5N2              
#> 2 V2       PRO2    PEP2    H5N2              
#> 3 V3       PRO3    PEP3    N3N2              
#> 4 V4       PRO3    PEP4    N3N2

Think of this as your molecular address book - every variable gets its own detailed profile.

ğŸ“‹ Sample Information - Know Your Experiments 

get_sample_info(toy_exp)
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
#>   sample group batch
#>   <chr>  <chr> <dbl>
#> 1 S1     A         1
#> 2 S2     A         2
#> 3 S3     A         1
#> 4 S4     B         2
#> 5 S5     B         1
#> 6 S6     B         2

And this? This is your experimental diary - tracking every condition, timepoint, and treatment.

Hereâ€™s the cool part: Notice how the â€œvariableâ€ column in get_var_info() and the â€œsampleâ€ column in get_sample_info() perfectly match the row and column names in your expression matrix? Thatâ€™s no accident!

These are the index columns - the secret sauce that keeps everything synchronized. Theyâ€™re like the GPS coordinates that ensure your data stays connected no matter what transformations you throw at it.

Data Wrangling Made Easy - dplyr Meets glyexp

If youâ€™ve ever used dplyr (and who hasnâ€™t?), youâ€™re already 90% of the way there! ğŸ‰

For every dplyr function you know and love, glyexp gives you two specialized versions:

  • _samples() functions: work on your sample metadata
  • _variables() functions: work on your variable annotations

Letâ€™s see this in action. Want to focus on just group â€œAâ€ samples?

subset_exp <- filter_samples(toy_exp, group == "A")

Letâ€™s check what happened to our sample info:

get_sample_info(subset_exp)
#> # A tibble: 3 Ã— 3
#>   sample group batch
#>   <chr>  <chr> <dbl>
#> 1 S1     A         1
#> 2 S2     A         2
#> 3 S3     A         1

Beautiful! But hereâ€™s where the magic really shines - check out the expression matrix:

get_expr_mat(subset_exp)
#>    S1 S2 S3
#> V1  1  5  9
#> V2  2  6 10
#> V3  3  7 11
#> V4  4  8 12

ğŸª Ta-da! The expression matrix automatically filtered itself to match! Itâ€™s like having a well-trained assistant who anticipates your every move.

This is filter_samples() in a nutshell: â€œHey, filter my sample info this way, and oh yeah, make sure everything else follows suit.â€ And it does, flawlessly.

Variable filtering works the same way:

toy_exp |>
  filter_samples(group == "A") |>
  filter_variables(glycan_composition == "H5N2") |>
  get_expr_mat()
#>    S1 S2 S3
#> V1  1  5  9
#> V2  2  6 10

Notice how these functions support the pipe operator (|>)? Thatâ€™s the dplyr DNA in action!

The pattern is simple: glyexp functions are just like their dplyr cousins, but with two superpowers:

  1. They expect and return experiment() objects (keeping your data ecosystem intact)
  2. They treat those index columns like precious cargo (no accidental deletions here!)

The Sacred Index Columns - Handle with Care

Remember those index columns we mentioned? Hereâ€™s the golden rule: Donâ€™t mess with them directly!

Think of them as the foundation of your data house - you can redecorate all you want, but donâ€™t touch the support beams.

Want to select specific columns from your sample info? Easy:

toy_exp |>
  select_samples(group) |>
  get_sample_info()
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 2
#>   sample group
#>   <chr>  <chr>
#> 1 S1     A    
#> 2 S2     A    
#> 3 S3     A    
#> 4 S4     B    
#> 5 S5     B    
#> 6 S6     B

See how the â€œsampleâ€ column (our trusty index) stuck around? Thatâ€™s glyexp being protective of your data integrity.

Even when you try to be sneaky, itâ€™s got your back:

toy_exp |>
  select_samples(-starts_with("sample")) |>
  get_sample_info()
#> # A tibble: 6 Ã— 3
#>   sample group batch
#>   <chr>  <chr> <dbl>
#> 1 S1     A         1
#> 2 S2     A         2
#> 3 S3     A         1
#> 4 S4     B         2
#> 5 S5     B         1
#> 6 S6     B         2

Nice try, but that index column isnâ€™t going anywhere! ğŸ˜„

Slicing and Dicing - Matrix-Style Subsetting

Want to subset your experiment? Think matrix indexing, but smarter:

subset_exp <- toy_exp[, 1:3]

This grabs the first 3 samples, and like a good butler, updates everything else accordingly:

get_expr_mat(subset_exp)
#>    S1 S2 S3
#> V1  1  5  9
#> V2  2  6 10
#> V3  3  7 11
#> V4  4  8 12
get_sample_info(subset_exp)
#> # A tibble: 3 Ã— 3
#>   sample group batch
#>   <chr>  <chr> <dbl>
#> 1 S1     A         1
#> 2 S2     A         2
#> 3 S3     A         1

Both the expression matrix and sample info are perfectly in sync. Itâ€™s like theyâ€™re dancing to the same tune!

When You Need to Break Free - The Tibble Escape Hatch

The glycoverse ecosystem is pretty comprehensive, but we know there are times when you need to venture beyond our cozy world. When that moment comes, as_tibble() is your bridge to the broader R universe:

as_tibble(toy_exp)
#> # A tibble: 24 Ã— 8
#>    sample group batch variable protein peptide glycan_composition value
#>    <chr>  <chr> <dbl> <chr>    <chr>   <chr>   <chr>              <int>
#>  1 S1     A         1 V1       PRO1    PEP1    H5N2                   1
#>  2 S2     A         2 V1       PRO1    PEP1    H5N2                   5
#>  3 S3     A         1 V1       PRO1    PEP1    H5N2                   9
#>  4 S4     B         2 V1       PRO1    PEP1    H5N2                  13
#>  5 S5     B         1 V1       PRO1    PEP1    H5N2                  17
#>  6 S6     B         2 V1       PRO1    PEP1    H5N2                  21
#>  7 S1     A         1 V2       PRO2    PEP2    H5N2                   2
#>  8 S2     A         2 V2       PRO2    PEP2    H5N2                   6
#>  9 S3     A         1 V2       PRO2    PEP2    H5N2                  10
#> 10 S4     B         2 V2       PRO2    PEP2    H5N2                  14
#> # â„¹ 14 more rows

This transforms your experiment() into a beautiful, tidy tibble (what the cool kids call â€œlong formatâ€). Every row is an observation, every column is a variable - the gold standard for data analysis (see what is tidy data).

Pro tip: These tibbles can get really long (think novel-length), especially with all that rich metadata. Smart analysts filter their experiments first:

toy_exp |>
  filter_variables(glycan_composition == "H5N2") |>
  select_samples(group) |>
  select_variables(-glycan_composition) |>
  as_tibble()
#> # A tibble: 12 Ã— 6
#>    sample group variable protein peptide value
#>    <chr>  <chr> <chr>    <chr>   <chr>   <int>
#>  1 S1     A     V1       PRO1    PEP1        1
#>  2 S2     A     V1       PRO1    PEP1        5
#>  3 S3     A     V1       PRO1    PEP1        9
#>  4 S4     B     V1       PRO1    PEP1       13
#>  5 S5     B     V1       PRO1    PEP1       17
#>  6 S6     B     V1       PRO1    PEP1       21
#>  7 S1     A     V2       PRO2    PEP2        2
#>  8 S2     A     V2       PRO2    PEP2        6
#>  9 S3     A     V2       PRO2    PEP2       10
#> 10 S4     B     V2       PRO2    PEP2       14
#> 11 S5     B     V2       PRO2    PEP2       18
#> 12 S6     B     V2       PRO2    PEP2       22

Much more manageable, right?

Standing on the Shoulders of Giants

Designing experiment() wasnâ€™t done in a vacuum - we learned from some amazing predecessors:

SummarizedExperiment ğŸ“Š
The granddaddy of omics data containers from Bioconductor. Solid as a rock for RNA-seq, but not quite â€œtidyâ€ enough for our taste.

tidySummarizedExperiment ğŸ§¹
A brilliant attempt to bring tidy principles to SummarizedExperiment from the tidySummarizedExperiment package. We love the concept, but felt that cramming everything into one tibble doesnâ€™t quite capture the mental model of separated data types.

massdataset ğŸ”¬
Our closest cousin! The massdataset package gets so many things right - tidy operations, clean data separation, perfect for mass spec data. We especially admire its data processing history tracking (reproducibility FTW!).

But hereâ€™s our twist: while object-oriented programming has its merits, we believe most R users think functionally. Your code is your reproducibility trail - elegant, transparent, and familiar to every R user.

Our Philosophy ğŸ’­
We chose the functional programming path because it feels like home to R users. No hidden states, no mysterious transformations - just clear, chainable functions that do exactly what they say on the tin.

Huge thanks to all the developers who paved this road. glyexp exists because of your groundbreaking work! ğŸ™
